fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Word document containing pipe character ( "|" ) when imported into Confluence, end up creating tables, instead of just displaying the pipe character.

h3. Environment
* Pages imported from Word documents;

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a Word document containing two or more pipe characters (or use the file provided in this BUG);
 # Import this document into Confluence using *...* > *Import Word Document* functionality;

* [^Word Import Pipe test.docx] 

h3. Expected Results
* Pipe characters to be displayed on Confluence's page
 !Screen Shot 2019-05-01 at 10.19.15.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Actual Results
* Pipe characters are interpreted and end up being displayed as a table, as can be seen in the next screenshot.
 !Screen Shot 2019-05-01 at 10.39.33.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Notes
* This is probably due to Confluence's markdown interpreter that is not escaping the pipe character.

h3. Workaround
The current workaround for this issue would be escaping the character in the original Word document by using "\|" instead of just "|".
(The second line of this Word document contained escaped pipe characters, as can be seen in the next screenshot, and correctly displayed the pipe characters when imported into Confluence)
 !Screen Shot 2019-05-01 at 10.19.15.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Word document containing pipe character ( "|" ) when imported into Confluence, end up creating tables, instead of just displaying the pipe character

fields.description:

Currently, the only way to sent a google document to a Confluence page is by using the [Google Drive macros|https://confluence.atlassian.com/confcloud/google-drive-macros-737182322.html]. There's no direct way to publish the document directly to Confluence.

Create the integration from Google's side. This would be done through an add-on, as we've previously made with [Jira Cloud for Sheets \- G Suite Marketplace|https://gsuite.google.com/marketplace/app/jira_cloud_for_sheets/1065669263016] and [Atlassian Cloud \- G Suite Marketplace|https://gsuite.google.com/marketplace/app/atlassian_cloud/689852235462].

None

fields.description:
Like many large services companies we have many users on our cloud instances (and rapidly growing).
As our Atlassian usage grows so does our Atlassian bills, and we need better ways of recovering our running costs from the various business units involved.
We can currently merge information from AzureAD with the Atlassian accounts and can tie an Atlassian account to a business unit which is great!
However if a business unit enables access to an external user for either Confluence or Jira, then we don't have the requesting business unit information available out of the APIs as this information is not stored.
We suggest that a simple 10 character alphanumeric field is added to each user that could be populated with some sort of charge back code.
Provided this field would be available via the API, this would help us with internal cost recovery.
This is a simple request but would provide positive benefits to large cloud instance users and would remove some of the barriers to growth.
fields.summary: Ability to assign users to a chargeback code.

fields.description:
{panel:title=Status Update 18 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ff7f7f|titleBGColor=#ff7f7f|bgColor=#e5e5e5}
Hi everyone!

This feature has now been implemented and released to all customers, try it out either by clicking the search button in the top right corner, or using the keyboard shortcut (Ctrl + F on Windows, Cmd + F on Mac). Hope you like it, and let us know any feedback you have :)

Heather
{panel}
h3. Description

The *Find&Replace* function was removed from the new editing experience. According to the  *[Confluence Cloud Editor Roadmap|https://confluence.atlassian.com/confcloud/confluence-cloud-editor-roadmap-967314556.html#ConfluenceCloudEditorRoadmap-Findandreplace]*:
{quote}"_*Find and replace*
 We removed *find* as this function is also provided by all web browsers. Press *Ctrl + F* (Windows) or *Cmd + F* (Mac) to use find.

There is no workaround for *replace*. If this feature was valuable to you, please let us know._"
{quote}
 
 Should be extremely useful to have this functionality in our new editor.
fields.summary: Replace, from Find & Replace function, in the new editor

fields.description:
Hi team,

I'm trying to create a Confluence Cloud App that needs to create Groups in Confluence.  I'm surprised that the rest API in Confluence is incomplete. There is no way to:
* Create/Delete/Update Group
* Added/Remove members to/From a Group

https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/confluence/rest/#api-group-get

At the moment, you can on read information from groups.

My current workaround is using the Jira API that allows the operations I need. In the cloud, groups are shared between Jira and Confluence.

https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/rest/v3/?utm_source=%2Fcloud%2Fjira%2Fplatform%2Frest%2F&utm_medium=302#api-rest-api-3-group-post

The addon needs to ask the user for special JIRA permissions using 3LO.

Would you add the rest methods to Confluence? Could you allow Confluence apps to have access to Jira Rest API? (maybe with a special Scope).
fields.summary: Missing Group Rest API methods in Confluence

fields.description:
We are transitioning a lot of our documentation from Google Docs to Confluence. Our users have expressed that real-time collaboration is _the_ top thing that makes transitioning some of our use of Google Docs difficult.

I think that live, shared editing works well enough (though maybe a little less smoothly than Google's implementation). Inline comments are the big problem, though.
 # Needing to reload the page when new comments arrive is a huge hurdle
 ## In Google Docs, new comments are displayed immediately in the correct place.
 # Not being able to see comments in edit mode makes real-time collaboration far less useful
 ## In Google Docs, inline comments are displayed to the right side of the main text

These two changes to inline comments should close the gap with Google Docs and make the move to Confluence an unequivocal win for our users.
fields.summary: Inline comments and real-time collaboration that work more like Google Docs

fields.description:
Hello,

I had a discussion with a guy from our security team and he made those following commentaries about the Atlassian Companion:

"There are three things that annoy me a  little:

- Locally edited files are retained even after they are uploaded to Confluence (in the C: \ Users \ <username> \. Atlassian-companion \ directory [1]
- The product logs are very verbose and indicate absolutely everything that has been done. They keep a record of the secret used by Companion to send documents on your behalf via the REST API [2]
- The product is not yet tested and could suffer from flaws that would facilitate the compromise of the machine (it is a soft more to maintain ...)

Since Confluence has not been put into production to serve as GED or SharePoint and we have very little perspective on this product and its future (switching to a paid mode), I would advise you to disable its integration in Confluence based on @ https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/administering-the-atlassian-companion-app-958456281.html, under "Disable File Editing"

Can you please give use your perspective about the security guy's comment ?

Kind Regards,
Michel
fields.summary: Atlassian Companion

h3. Issue Summary
Creating a browser keyword search to perform searches on Confluence advanced search scoped to a space doesn't work at first because it displays all the contents of the space, only after an additional "enter" in the advanced search the search actually filters by the search parameters.

h3. Environment

This is mostly a Firefox feature as far as I know, but might affect other browsers as well if they have this feature.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Click the search icon in the left sidebar.
# Click "Advanced Search" at the bottom of the search panel to go to the advanced search.
# Select a space in the "IN SPACE" dropdown on the left to narrow the search to one specific space.
# Right click in the "Search Confluence" field and select "Add a Keyword for this Search..."
# Click the Keyword field and name it something, on my tests it was named "wiki" then click save.
# Open a new browser tab. In the address bar, type "wiki" to search using the keyword search + some text related to the space selected on step #3

h3. Expected Results
The Confluence search page appears displaying only contents related to the text used in the keyword search.
h3. Actual Results

The Confluence search page appears displaying every page in the space as the search result, not filtering the search by the text.

h3. Workaround

After the Confluence Advanced Search page is loaded, the Confluence search bar contains the text that was typed in the browser's URL field, and the cursor is there, so if you hit the Enter/Return key the search applies and the contents are filtered by the text, so the workaround is just hitting an extra Enter/Return.
fields.summary: Browser search keyword doesn't work

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
We’re in the process of migrating our Confluence app. We’ve previously relied on the body.storage response from {{/wiki/rest/api/content/\{id\}}} which returns the page content in XML format. In there, we look for <ri:user ri:userkey=“8a7f808360575f7501606910dc1600cb” /> tags to identify users when they are mentioned.

These tags are not updated to use Account IDs when calling the REST API with the privacyMode flag and updating the apiMigrations gdpr flag in the descriptor. Do you have any plans to update the body.storage XML or is there another way to get mentions in a Confluence page with Account IDs?

h3. Notes
* Raised in [Atlassian Developer Community|https://developer.atlassian.com/community/] (see [this post|https://community.developer.atlassian.com/t/weekly-gdpr-api-status-development-update-march-14/27942/3]).

h3. Workaround
The body.editor2 format seems to return tags including an Atlassian Account ID. Should we use those instead? On https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/confluence/rest/#api-content-post it is mentioned that “Note, editor2 format is used by Atlassian only.” and I want to make sure we don’t have to do another migration anytime soon.
fields.summary: Confluence Userkey/AccountIDs in body.storage response

Our team has been notified. If the problem persists, please contact Atlassian Support.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Publishing from Preview causes blank page

h3. Environment
Confluence Cloud Legacy Editor 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new page and publish it
# Go to *Edit* mode
# Make some changes to the page
# Click *...* > *Preview*
# Publish the page

h3. Expected Results
Page will be published as expected

h3. Actual Results
Page is published without any content.
Its storage format is now empty and to retrieve the previous content, you must navigate to *...* > *Page History* and restore from a previous version.

h3. Notes
* Only replicated in Microsoft Internet Explorer 11
* Not reproducible 100% of the times

h3. Workaround
* Go to *Page History*
* Pick the second to last version and Restore from it
fields.summary: Publishing from Preview causes blank page

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Having a draft to a page where there's a specific user mentioned, if this user is deleted, it will not be possible to publish the draft.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Mention a specific user on a page and publish it
# Edit the page and close it without publishing
# Delete that specific user
# Try to publish that draft

h3. Expected Results
The draft should be published

h3. Actual Results
The draft is not published, the message "There was an error processing the request." is shown on the page and on the browser's console:
|  !Screen Shot 2019-04-10 at 16.59.31.png|thumbnail!  |
{code}jquery-min.js:1 PUT https://<instance>.atlassian.net/wiki/rest/api/content/789545067?status=draft 400{code}
Errors on internal log:
{code:none}Uncaught exception thrown by REST service: Could not unmarshal a link in the editor.	{code}

h3. Notes
This is noticed on the legacy editor only.

h3. Workaround
Remove the former user's mention, refresh the page a couple of times and try to publish it again.
fields.summary: Not able to publish draft when there's a former user mentioned

Team Calendars is an add-on which comes +pre-installed+ on Confluence. If the user wants to enable it, then he/she proceed with this action of enable it.

h3. Environment
 * Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Access the *Manage Add-ons* section in the Confluence settings;
# You can see Team Calendars as a *user-installed* add-on.

h3. Expected Results
Team Calendars should be in System-installed apps, as it comes by default when the instance is created.

h3. Actual Results
Team Calendars is being shown as a user-installed app.

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Team Calendars presenting as "user-installed"

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
In a case where the Team Calendars is not enabled, if you write the URL https://SITE_NAME.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SPACE_KEY/calendars, it will redirect you to a calendar page that actually was not created before.

h3. Environment
 * Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Access an instance which doesn't have Team Calendars enabled;
# Access any existing space;
# Change the URL to https://SITE_NAME.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SPACE_KEY/calendars;
# You will get a Team Calendars page that was not previously created, saying you do not have a Team Calendars license;
# Go to *Confluence Dashboard > Activity > All updates*;
# The page is listed there as recently updated to all users.

h3. Expected Results
By manually accessing this URL, once the Team Calendars is not enabled in the instance, Confluence should redirects us to a not found page, once it even is created.

h3. Actual Results
At the moment you access the URL, Confluence automatically creates a Team Calendars page without the user consent.

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Team Calendars pages being created accessing the URL

fields.description:
*Allow a Next Gen Jira Roadmap to be embedded into a confluence page as a live Jira chart / macro.*  

It would be beneficial to be able to display project progress to Confluence users as not all our company are given access to Jira so they cannot view the project roadmaps in the project itself. 

By allowing embedding of a live Jira next Gen roadmap to confluence it will give our confluence users the ability to view tech plans and schedules and assist in allowing our business and tech teams to work better together through enhanced project visibility. 

It will also cut down on having to keep the Jira - Roadmap planner Macro up to date manually each time Epic priorities change in Jira

Alternatively having the Roadmap planner widget sync to and render out an existing Jira Next Gen roadmap with additional features would be great.  It seems like a single roadmap function across Jira and Confluence would really assist many people with functionality they desperately need to do project planning with.
fields.summary: Allow JIRA Next Gen Roadmap to be added to confluence page as an updating Macro
